metadata.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay City v. Assessee

facts.text: The assessee is a Private Limited Company incorporated in June 1945 by converting an erstwhile partnership firm into a Private Limited Company.

The partnership firm entered into a managing agency agreement on June 15, 1933 with The Century Spinning and Manufacturing Co. Ltd. Under the agreement, the assessee was to continue as managing agents for a minimum period of 21 years and thereafter until the firm chose to resign or was removed.

During the 21-year period, the managed company had no right to remove the managing agents except for reasons in clause 15. Remuneration: minimum Rs. 6,000 per month, or additional to make 10% of gross profits if less.
Clause 14: If deprived of office for reasons other than clause 15, entitled to compensation equal to aggregate monthly salary of not less than Rs. 6,000 for unexpired portion of 21 years.
In April 1951, a large holding of the managed company acquired by hostile shareholders. Relationship strained.
On April 23, 1951, Directors of managed company passed resolution terminating services of assessee as managing agents.
Resolution affirmed by shareholders at extraordinary general meeting on May 23, 1951.
Notice of termination issued on April 23, 1951.
Assessee claimed Rs. 50 lakhs compensation for unlawful termination.
Managed company offered Rs. 2,34,000 as compensation (Rs. 6,000/month for 3 years 2 months 7 days unexpired + Rs. 4,600 for 23 days April 1951).

Assessee sued managed company in Bombay High Court for Rs. 28 lakhs. Suit decreed on November 17, 1955 for Rs. 2,34,000, affirmed in appeal. Courts held entitled only to liquidated damages at Rs. 6,000/month.
Assessee received decreed amount in December 1955.
Assessee under voluntary liquidation at relevant time. Maintained accounts on mercantile system.
S. 10(5A) inserted by Finance Act 1955 (not retrospective). Deems compensation received by managing agent at termination as business profits.
In assessment year 1956-57, ITO included Rs. 2,34,000 as business profits overruling assessee's objection that it accrued in 1951.
AAC upheld ITO: amount due when decreed Nov 17, 1955.
Tribunal: compensation due April 23, 1951, not taxable 1956-57.
Tribunal referred under s.66(1): 1. Accrued April 23,1951? 2. Taxable under s.10(5A) 1956-57?
Bombay High Court: Yes to first; compensation not taxable 1956-57, interest yes.

legal_issues.text: Whether on the facts and circumstances, the compensation for termination of managing agency accrued to the assessee on April 23, 1951?
Whether the compensation of Rs. 2,34,000 and interest thereon was taxable under s. 10(5A) of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922 in assessment year 1956-57?

petitioner_arguments.text: Amount became due only when decreed by High Court on Nov 17, 1955, as assessee disputed quantum.
S.10(5A) is a code in itself; no reliance on assessee's system of accountancy. Liability new, receipt post-insertion, deem due in Dec 1955.

respondent_arguments.text: Receipt cannot be taxed in 1956-57 as it became due in 1951 under mercantile system.
Under agreement, entitled to definite liquidated damages of Rs. 6,000/month from April 23, 1951.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Clauses 14 and 15 of managing agency agreement

court_reasoning.text: Termination not under clause 15; entitled to liquidated damages under clause 14: definite sum of Rs. 6,000/month for unexpired term. Clause 14 quantified damages independently of clause 10.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Assessee entitled to definite sum under clause 14; accrued April 23, 1951.

court_reasoning.text: S.10(5A) covers 'due to or received by'. For mercantile system (assessee's), 'due to' applies; right accrued April 1951. Dispute over quantum does not make right contingent.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Assessee's right to compensation arose in April 1951 under mercantile system.

court_reasoning.text: S.10(5A) integral part of Act; tax liability based on assessee's adopted system. Actual entries irrelevant; method matters.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No basis to ignore mercantile system for s.10(5A).

holdings.text: Compensation accrued to assessee on April 23, 1951.
Compensation of Rs. 2,34,000 not liable to tax under s.10(5A) in assessment year 1956-57 (interest taxable).

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras v. A. Gajapathy Naidu
precedents_cited.relevance: ITO must consider assessee's accountancy system and when right to receive accrued.

precedents_cited.case_name: Thiagaraja Chettiar Co. v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras
precedents_cited.relevance: Remuneration accrues when entitled under agreement, despite disputes or non-entry in accounts.

precedents_cited.case_name: F.E. Hardcastle Co. Private Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income Tax, Bombay City
precedents_cited.relevance: Similar ratio on accrual despite disputes.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income-tax Act, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: S.10(5A) deems termination compensation as business profits; applies 'due to or received' based on accountancy system. S.66(1) for reference.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court agreed with Bombay High Court: compensation accrued April 23, 1951, and under assessee's mercantile system, not taxable under S.10(5A) in 1956-57 (interest taxable). Appeal by Commissioner dismissed.
outcome.relief_granted: None; upheld High Court decision in favour of assessee on compensation.

key_quotes.text: "In case the firm shall be deprived of the office of Agents of the Company for any reason or cause other than or except those reasons or causes specified in clause fifteen of these presents the firm shall be entitled to receive from the Company as compensation or liquidated damages..."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Clause 14 defining right to definite liquidated damages.

key_quotes.text: "S. 10(5A) provided that any compensation or other payment due to or received by a managing agent... shall be deemed to be profits and gains of a business..."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key provision interpreted based on accountancy system.

key_quotes.text: "The fact that the assessee was claiming an exorbitant sum to which it was not entitled to will not convert its right into a contingent right."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Right accrued despite dispute over quantum.
